Package jetbrains.mps.project

Class ProjectBase

  • java.lang.Object
    • jetbrains.mps.project.Project
      • jetbrains.mps.project.ProjectBase
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IProject, MPSModuleOwner, Project
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FileMPSProject
    public abstract class ProjectBase
extends Project
    MPS Project basic implementation. Stores a set of modules. Set of modules coincide with the modules in the underlying repository. Supported always by a ProjectDescriptor which stores paths to the module descriptors Doesn't manage lifecycle of a module descriptors other than "update 'em all" on demand. Check ModuleFileChangeListener of [mps-platform] for change tracking. However, tracks module renames (albeit in a bit weird way) to keep inner structures fit. This project is tied to MPS platform and gives access to MPS core platform and components it comprises. FIXME poor architecture results in the intertwined control flow between ProjectBase, ModuleLoader and ProjectDescriptor I guess that removing virtual folders solves all the problem
    See Also:
    ProjectDescriptor

      • getErrors

      • getPath

        @Nullable

      • addModule

        public final void addModule​(@NotNull
                            SModule module)
        Locks: at the moment, method grabs model write on the project repository one it registers module in there. It's up to client to grab model write on a project repo in case he needs to batch addition of multiple modules. The reason I decided to keep code to grab model write inside the method is that I plan to make module instantiation without registration mainstream (unlike what's currently happens in MRF.instantiateModule(), which instantiates and registers module right away, therefore clients usually possess model lock already).

      • removeModule

        public final void removeModule​(@NotNull
                               SModule module)
        force removal of the module from the project

      • getProjectModules

        @NotNull
public final List<SModule> getProjectModules()
        Returns:
        all the modules this project owns (todo: contract to be: the same modules are in the #getRepository() repository) currently #getRepository returns the global repository (singleton) which hosts all the modules in the environment

        Effective way to tell if a module is part of the project Note, Generator modules owned by a Language from the project are deemed project modules, too.

        public final void projectOpened()

      • loadDescriptor

        protected final void loadDescriptor​(@NotNull
                                    ProjectDataSource dataSource)
        calls ProjectDataSource.loadDescriptor() and set the new project descriptor makes sense to use this method with the update() together to avoid the inconsistency between the project modules and the descriptor state.
